Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I stood in the crowded hallway of the polling station, ballot in hand, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. My sister’s name flashed on the screen—she never called twice unless it was serious. I answered, and her shaky voice told me she’d just had a panic attack and needed me to come home. My heart twisted; I’d always promised to be there for her, especially when she was struggling. But the election official was already waving me over, explaining that my registration had a mismatch. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form, and the station would close in ten minutes. I could see the expectation in the official’s eyes: follow the rules, don’t hold up the process. But my sister’s voice echoed in my mind, pleading for help. I felt torn in two, the weight of both responsibilities pressing down on me, unsure which role I was supposed to honor in that moment.
